name: Project Risk Register Evaluator
description: Evaluates risk registers for identification completeness, scoring rigor, response planning quality, and monitoring discipline

scale.1: Minimal risks identified (<10), single category only, vague descriptions
scale.2: Some risks (10-15) but gaps in categories, mix of vague and specific
scale.3: Good coverage (15-25 risks) across most categories, mostly specific
scale.4: Comprehensive (20-30 risks) across all categories (tech/schedule/resource/external/scope/org), all specific
scale.5: Exemplary (25-35 risks) with structured brainstorming evidence, specific root-cause level risks, appropriate granularity, both threats and opportunities identified

scale.1: No scoring or arbitrary scores, no rationale, probability/impact conflated
scale.2: Basic scoring but clustered (all 6-9), weak rationale, single-person assessment
scale.3: Scores differentiated across range, basic rationale, some expert input
scale.4: Well-differentiated scores (use full 1-25 range), clear rationale for High/Critical risks, multi-stakeholder input
scale.5: Exemplary scoring with calibration evidence (base rates, reference class), detailed rationale for all High/Critical risks, probability/impact assessed independently, bias mitigation techniques used (silent voting, historical data)

scale.1: No prioritization or risk matrix, risks listed randomly
scale.2: Basic priority labels but no matrix, unclear thresholds
scale.3: Risk matrix plotted, priority thresholds defined (Critical/High/Medium/Low), risks categorized
scale.4: Clear risk matrix with all risks plotted, priority thresholds explicit (e.g., Critical ≥20), focus on High/Critical risks evident
scale.5: Exemplary visualization with risk matrix, priority distribution makes sense for project phase (high uncertainty at start), Critical risks (≥20) escalated, risk profile matches project context

scale.1: No response plans, or vague actions like 'monitor closely' with no owners
scale.2: Minimal response plans for some High risks, vague actions, no contingencies, teams assigned (not individuals)
scale.3: Response plans for High/Critical risks with mitigation OR contingency (not both), named owners, basic specificity
scale.4: Strong response plans for High/Critical risks with specific mitigation AND contingency, named owners, deadlines, triggers defined
scale.5: Exemplary response plans with SMART mitigation actions (specific, measurable, assigned, realistic, time-bound), detailed contingencies with quantifiable triggers, backup resources identified, investment vs risk reduction justified

scale.1: No distinction between mitigation and contingency, or only one type present
scale.2: Some distinction but often confused (contingencies described as mitigations)
scale.3: Clear distinction for most risks: mitigation (reduce probability before) vs contingency (reduce impact if occurs)
scale.4: Explicit distinction for all High/Critical risks, mitigation targets probability, contingency has activation triggers
scale.5: Exemplary distinction with mitigation goals (probability X→Y by date), contingency triggers are specific and measurable, investment in each type justified

scale.1: No monitoring plan, register created once and never updated
scale.2: Basic review frequency stated but no evidence of updates, no leading indicators
scale.3: Regular reviews (weekly/monthly) with some risk score updates, new/closed risks tracked
scale.4: Disciplined monitoring with regular reviews, risk score changes documented with rationale, leading indicators identified for High/Critical risks, trend analysis (improving/stable/deteriorating)
scale.5: Exemplary monitoring with review log showing risk evolution, leading indicators tracked with thresholds, risk burn-down chart showing total exposure decreasing, escalation procedures for breaches, lessons learned captured

scale.1: No risk owners assigned, or generic 'team' ownership
scale.2: Some risks have owners but inconsistent, or teams assigned instead of individuals
scale.3: Named individuals assigned to most High/Critical risks
scale.4: All High/Critical risks have named owners (not teams), owner responsibilities clear (monitor, mitigate, escalate)
scale.5: Exemplary ownership with named owners for all High/Critical risks, owner responsibilities explicit, accountability mechanisms (review meetings, status updates), escalation paths defined

scale.1: Risk register separate from project plan, no integration
scale.2: Risk register exists but not referenced in project plan or schedule
scale.3: Some integration: mitigation actions mentioned in project plan, but not formally scheduled
scale.4: Good integration: mitigation actions scheduled in project plan with resources, contingency reserves budgeted
scale.5: Exemplary integration: mitigation actions in project schedule with owners and deadlines, risk-adjusted timeline (P50/P80/P95), contingency reserves in budget, risk reviews in milestone gates

kickoff.typical_risk_profile: 20-40 risks, many at Medium score (uncertainty high), few Critical (pre-mitigation)
kickoff.focus: Comprehensive risk identification across all categories, baseline assessment

mid_project.typical_risk_profile: 15-30 risks, Critical risks mitigated to Medium/Low, new integration/dependency risks emerge
mid_project.focus: Risk evolution tracking, new risks from integration, mitigation progress
red_flags: Risk velocity positive (opening faster than closing)

near_completion.typical_risk_profile: 10-20 risks, mostly Low (resolved), few High (deployment, cutover, training)
near_completion.focus: Launch risks, rollback contingencies, final acceptance risks
red_flags: New Critical risks emerging late (missed earlier)

too_few_risks.root_cause: Incomplete brainstorming, single category focus, not enough time spent
too_few_risks.fix: Use structured brainstorming by category (technical, schedule, resource, external, scope, org), involve diverse stakeholders, allocate 1-2 hours for risk workshop

all_medium_scores.root_cause: Lack of calibration, avoiding hard choices, consensus-seeking without debate
all_medium_scores.fix: Use reference risks for calibration, force ranking for ties, silent voting to avoid groupthink, use full 1-25 range

no_owners.symptom: Risks assigned to 'team' or no owner
no_owners.fix: Assign named individuals (not teams) to all High/Critical risks, make ownership explicit in review meetings

vague_responses.root_cause: Lack of specificity, not enough time to plan properly
vague_responses.fix: Use SMART criteria (specific, measurable, assigned, realistic, time-bound), define contingency triggers quantitatively

stale_register.symptom: Register created at kickoff, never updated
stale_register.root_cause: No review cadence, not integrated into workflow, PM too busy
stale_register.fix: Schedule weekly review for High/Critical risks (15 min), integrate risk review into existing status meetings, use monitoring log template

no_contingencies.root_cause: Optimism bias ('mitigation will work'), not understanding mitigation vs contingency
no_contingencies.fix: Assume some mitigations fail, create backup plans for High/Critical risks, define triggers for contingency activation

overall: Risk scores differentiated (use full 1-25 range, not clustered)
All High/Critical risks have named owners, mitigation, contingency, triggers
Scoring rationale documented with base rates or historical data
Risk matrix plotted with priority thresholds explicit
Regular monitoring with risk evolution tracked (new/closed/changed)
Mitigation actions scheduled in project plan with deadlines
Contingency reserves budgeted based on EMV or Monte Carlo
Risk profile matches project phase (decreasing over time)
quantitative: Monte Carlo simulation for timeline/budget forecasting (P50/P80/P95)
Expected Monetary Value (EMV) calculated for sizing reserves
Three-point estimation (PERT) for task durations with uncertainty
Sensitivity analysis (tornado diagram) showing biggest impact drivers
Risk burn-down chart showing total exposure decreasing over time
organizational: Lessons learned database referenced for probability calibration
Risk maturity level ≥3 (managed: regular reviews, tracked mitigation)
Blameless risk culture (no shooting messenger, proactive identification rewarded)
Historical risk data tracked (actual vs estimated prob/impact for calibration)
